fields: \(A \implies B\)
"If A is true, B is also true." Does not express any causality like "because A is true, B is true".
{{c1::\( eg (A \land B) \)}} \( \equiv \) {{c2::\( eg A \lor eg B \)}}
de Morgan rules
{{c1::\( eg (A \lor B) \) }} \( \equiv \) {{c2::\( eg A \land eg B\)}}
De Morgan rules
Komplexer Kehrwert: {{c1::\( \frac{1}{z} \)}} \( = \) {{c2::\( \frac{x - iy}{x^2 + y^2}\)}}
What is the difference between propositional and predicate logic?

propositional: only values of \(\{0,1\}\), finite
predicate: any values in our universe, infinite
What is a predicate?

A k-ary predicate on \( U \) is a function \( U^k \rightarrow \{0,1\}\).
It's like a function that takes any number of arguments, but only returns boolean results.
What is a tautology?
A formula F (propositional logic) is a tautology/valid if it is true for all truth combinations of the involved symbols, so if it is always true. Symbol: \( \top \)
G is a logical conseqence of F. What does that mean?
\( F \models G\) if G is always true if F is true, but not necessarily false when F is false. (No causality!)
Predicate logic: universe
A universe is the non-empty set that we work within. Examples: \( \mathbb{N}, \mathbb{R}, \{ 0,1,2,3,6 \} \)
Was ist der Rang eines LGS?
Die Anzahl Pivotelemente bzw. die Anzahl Zeilen, welche nicht Nullzeilen sind.
Was ist der volle Rang eines LGS der Form \(m \times n\)?
\( r \le m, r \le n\), also ist der volle / maximale Rang \( r = \text{min}(m,n)\)
Proof method: "Composition of Implications"
Idea: If \( S \implies T \) and \( T \implies U \) are both true, then \( S \implies U \) is also true.
Proof method: "Direct Proof of an Implication"
Direct proof of \( S \implies T \): assume S and prove T under that assumption
Proof method: "Indirect Proof of an Implication"

Indirect proof of \( S \implies T \): Assume T is false, prove that S is false.

Follows from \( (\neg B \to \neg A) \models (A \to B) \)
Proof method: "Modus Ponens"

1. Find a suitable statement \(R\)
2. Prove \(R\)
3. Prove \(R \implies S\)
Proof method: "Case Distinction"

1. Find a finite list \( R_1, \ldots, R_k\) of statements (cases)
2. Prove that one case applies for the situation (prove one \(R_i\))
3. Prove \( R_i \implies S\) for \(i = 1, \ldots, k\)

Basically, show for all cases that they are correct.
Was ist eine symmetrische Matrix?

Eine symmetrische Matrix hat eine "Spiegelachse" an der Hauptdiagonale. Hauptdiagonale selber unwichtig!
Beispiel:
\( \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 5 & 1 \\ 5 & 2 & 4 \\ 1 & 4 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \)
Cardinality of a set
The number of elements in the set, written as \( |A| \).
Was ist eine transponierte Matrix?
Entlang der Hauptdiagonale gespiegelte Matrix \(\mathbf{A}^\top\), d.h. \( (\mathbf{A}^\top)_{ij} = (\mathbf{A})_{ji} \)
Was ist eine konjugiert-komplexe Matrix?
Wenn \(\mathbf{A}\) eine komplexe Matrix ist, dann ist \(\overline{\mathbf{A}}\) mit \( (\overline{\mathbf{A}})_{ij} = \overline{(\mathbf{A})_{ij}}\) die konjugiert-komplexe Matrix.
Was ist eine konjugiert-transponierte (auch: Hermitesch-transponierte) Matrix?
\( \mathbf{A}^H = (\overline{\mathbf{A}})^\top = \overline{\mathbf{A}^\top}\)
Wann ist eine Matrix Hermitesch?
Falls \( \mathbf{A}^H = A\)
Wann ist eine Matrix schiefsymmetrisch?

Falls \( \mathbf{A}^\top = -\mathbf{A}\)

Beispiel:
\( \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -3 & 5 \\ 3 & 0 & -4 \\ -5 & 4 & 0 \end{pmatrix}\)
Proof method: Proof by Contradiction

1. Find a suitable statement \( T\)
2. Prove that \( T \) is false
3. Assume that \( S \) is false and prove that \( T \) is true (-> contradiction)
Proof method: Existence Proof

We just want to prove that there exists a \( x \) such that a statement \( S_x \) is true. (e.g. There exists a prime number such that \( n - 10\) and \( n + 10\) are also prime.) 

constructive: We know the x.
non-constructive: We know that x has to exist, but we don't know its value.
Proof method: Pigeonhole Principle

If a set of \( n \) objects is divided into \( k  < n\) sets, then at least one of the sets contains at least \( \left \lceil{\frac{n}{k}}\right \rceil\) objects.

Informally: If there are more objects than sets, there is a set with more than one object in it.
Proof method: Proofs by counterexample
Special case of constructive existence proofs. By finding a counter example \( x\) such that \(S_x\) is not true, we can prove that \( S_i \) isn't always true.
Wann ist eine Matrix invertierbar?

Falls eine Matrix \( \mathbf{X} \) existiert, so dass \( \mathbf{AX} = \mathbf{XA} = \mathbf{I_n}\)

Beispiel: \( \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} * \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -\frac{2}{3} \\ 0 & \frac{1}{3} \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I_2}\)
Was ist eine regulre Matrix?

Eine Matrix \( A \) mit Rang \(A = n\). 
regulr \( \iff \) invertierbar
{{c1:: Inverse eines Produkts: \((\mathbf{AB})^{-1}\)}} = {{c2::\(\mathbf{B}^{-1} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\)}}
A relation  on a set A is called {{c1::reflexive}} if {{c2::\( a \ \rho \ a\) is true for all \( a \in A\), i.e. if \( \text{id} \subseteq \rho\).}}
Example: \( \ge, \le \) are reflexive, while \( <, > \) are not.
A relation  on a set A is called {{c1::symmetric}} if {{c2::\( a \ \rho \ b \iff b \ \rho \ a\) is true, i.e. if \( \rho = \hat{\rho}\)}}
Examples: \( \equiv_m\), marriage
A relation  on a set A is called {{c2::antisymmetric}} if {{c1::\( a \ \rho \ b \wedge b \ \rho \ a \implies a = b\) is true, i.e. if \( \rho \cap \hat{\rho} \subseteq \text{id}\)}}
Example: \( \le, \ge\) and the division relation: \( a \mid b \wedge b \mid a \implies a = b\)
A relation is {{c1::transitive}} if {{c2::\((a \ \rho \ b \wedge b \ \rho \ c) \implies a \ \rho \ c \) is true.}}
Examples: \( \le, \ge, <, |, \equiv_m\)
The {{c2::inverse relation}} is {{c1::\( a \ \rho \ b \iff b \ \hat{\rho} \ a\)}}.
Example: Inverse of parent relation is childhood relation. Also written as \( \rho^{-1}\)
Was ist eine orthogonale Matrix?
Fr eine orthogonale Matrix gilt \( \mathbf{A^\top A = I}_n\), d.h. die Inverse von A ist A transponiert. Orthogonal = reell, quadratisch, regulr
Was ist eine unitre Matrix?

Fr eine unitre Matrix gilt \( \mathbf{A^H A = I}_n\), d.h. die komplex-transponierte von A ist die Inverse von A. 
Unitr = regulr & quadratisch
Gilt fr zwei Matrizen \( \mathbf{A}\) und \( \mathbf{B}\), dass {{c2::\( \mathbf{AB} = \mathbf{BA}\)}}, dann {{c1::kommutieren}} diese Matrizen.
Eine {{c1::Linearkombination (LK)}} der Vektoren \( a_1, \ldots, a_n\) ist {{c2::ein Ausdruck der Form \( \alpha_1 a_1 + \cdots + \alpha_n a_n\) wobei \( \alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_n \in \mathbb{R}\)}}
Fr alle Vektorpaare \( \mathbf{x,y} \in \mathbb{E}^n \) gilt die Schwarzsche Ungleichung: {{c1::\( | \langle \mathbf{x, y} \rangle | \le ||\mathbf{x}|| \ ||\mathbf{y}||\)}}
(auch Cauchy-Schwarz-Ungleichung genannt)
Ein LGS heisst {{c1::homogen}}, wenn {{c2::die rechte Seite Null ist}}.
Besitzt immer triviale Lsung (alles 0).

{{c1::Eine Gruppe}} ist eine Menge {{c1::G mit Operation \( * \)}} mit folgenden Eigenschaften:
{{c2::
- Assoziotivitt: \((a * b) * c = a * (b*c)\)
- Neutrales Element existiert: \( a * e = e * a = e \)
- Inverse existiert: \( a * a^{-1} = a^{-1} * a = e\)
}}
Eine Gruppe \( (G, *) \) heisst {{c1::abelsch (auch: kommutativ)}}, falls \( * \) ausserdem {{c2::\(a * b = b * a\), also das Kommutativittgesetz erfllt}}.
Beispiel: \( (\mathbb{K}^{m\times n}, + ) \)

{{c1::Ein Krper}} ist eine Menge {{c1::\( \mathbb{K}\) mit Operationen \(+ , *\)}} mit folgenden Eigenschaften:
{{c2::
- \( (\mathbb{K}, +)\) ist eine abelsche Gruppe
- \( (\mathbb{K} \backslash \{0\}, *)\) ist eine abelsche Gruppe
- Distributivitt: \( a * (b+c) = a*b + a*c\)
}}
Beispiel: \( \mathbb{Q}, \mathbb{R}\)
{{c1::Ein Vektorraum}} ist eine Menge \( \mathbb{V}\) ber \( \mathbb{K}\), auf der {{c2::eine Addition und eine Skalarmultiplikation definiert ist.}}
Beispiele: \(\mathbb{R}^n, \mathbb{K}^{m\times n}, P_d(\mathbb{K})\) (Polynome von Grad \( \le d\))
Was ist ein Unterraum?

Ein Unterraum ist eine Teilmenge \( U \subseteq \mathbb{V}\) falls \( U \) auch die Eigenschaften eines Vektorraums hat (d.h. abgeschlossen bezglich Vektoraddition & Skalarmultiplikation). Beispiel: Ebene in \(\mathbb{R}^3\)
A function is {{c1::injective (or one-to-one)}} if {{c2::for \(a \ne b\) we have \(f(a) \ne f(b)\), i.e. no "collisions"}}
Example: \(f(x) = x\), counterexample: \(f(x) = x^2, x \in \mathbb{R}\)
A function \( f: A \rightarrow B\) is {{c1::surjective (or onto)}} if {{c2::\( \forall b \ \exists a \ , b = f(a)\), i.e. every value is taken}}
A function is {{c1::bijective (one-to-one correspondence)}} if it is {{c2::both injective and surjective.}}
The {{c2::power set of a set \(A\), denoted \(\mathcal{P}(A)\)}}, is {{c1::the set of all subsets of \(A\)}}.

{{c1::Equivalence relation}} is a relation on a set \(A\) that is
{{c2::
* reflexive
* symmetric
* transitive
}}
Example: \(\equiv_m \)

{{c1::A partial order}} on a set \(A\) is a relation that is
{{c2::
* reflexive
* antisymmetric
* transitive
}}
Examples: \(\leq, \geq\)
A set together with a partial order \(\preceq\) is called {{c1::a partially ordered set or simply poset.}}
Denoted \((A; \preceq)\)

{{c1::An algebra (also: algebraic structure, \( \Omega\)-algebra)}} is a pair \(\langle S, \Omega \rangle\) {{c2::where S is a set and \(\Omega = (\omega_1, \ldots, \omega_n)\) is a list of operations on S.}}
In an algebra \(\langle S, \Omega \rangle\), how is S usually called?
carrier (of the algebra)
{{c1::A monoid}} is an algebra {{c2::\( \langle M; *, e \rangle\) where \(*\) is associative and \(e\) is the neutral element.}}
Difference to group: Inverse missing
In a poset \( ( A; \preceq )\), \(b\) covers \(a\) if {{c1::\(a \prec b\) and there does not exist a \(c\) with \(a \prec c \land c \prec b \), so no elements are between \(a\) and \(b\).}}
Example: direct superior in a company
A poset \((A; \preceq)\) is called {{c2::totally ordered (also: linearly ordered) by \(\preceq\)}} if {{c1::any two elements of the poset are comparable.}}
Example: \((\mathbb{Z}; \ge)\)

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is a {{c1::minimal (maximal) element of \(A\)}} if {{c2::there exists no \(b \in A\) with \(b \prec a\) (\(b \succ a \) )}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is the {{c1::least (greatest) element of \(A\)}} if {{c2::\(a \preceq b\) (\(a \succeq b) \) for all \(b \in A\)}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is a {{c1::lower (upper) bound of \(S\)}} if {{c2::\(b \preceq a\) (\(b \succeq a) \) for all \(b \in S\)}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is the {{c1::greatest lower (least upper) bound of \(S\)}} if {{c2::\(a\) is the greatest (least) element of the set of all lower (upper) bounds of \(S\). }}
A poset \((A;\preceq)\) is well-ordered if {{c1::it is totally ordered and every non-empty subset has a least element.}}

Every totally ordered finite poset \(\rightarrow\) well-ordered
Infinite example: \((N; \le)\)
Infinite counterexample \((\mathbb{Z}; \le)\)
\((A;\preceq)\) is a poset. If \(\{a,b\}\) have a {{c2::greatest lower bound}}, then it is called the {{c1::meet of \(a\) and \(b\) (also denoted \(a \land b\)).}}
\((A;\preceq)\) is a poset. If \(\{a,b\}\) have a {{c2::least upper bound}}, then it is called the {{c1::join of \(a\) and \(b\) (also denoted \(a \lor b\)).}}
A poset in which {{c2::every pair of elements has a meet and a join}} is called a {{c1::lattice}}.
Examples: \((\mathbb{N}; \le), \ (\mathcal{P}(S); \subseteq)\)
The {{c2::subset \(f(A)\) of \(B\)}} is called the {{c1::image (also: range) of \(f\)}} and is also denoted \(Im(f)\).
Example: \(f(x) = x^2\), the range of \(f\) is \(\mathbb{R}^{\ge 0}\)
For a subset \(T\) of \(B\), the {{c1::preimage (in Linalg: Urbild) of \(T\), denoted \(f^{-1}(T)\)}}, is {{c2::the set of values in \(A\) that map into \(T\).}}
Example: \(f(x) = x^2\), the preimage of \([4,9]\) is \([-3,-2] \cup [2,3]\)
Two sets \(A, B\) are {{c1::equinumerous (denoted \(A \sim B\))}} if {{c2::there exists a bijection \(A \rightarrow B\).}}
Example: \(f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z} = (-1)^n \lceil n/2 \rceil\)
The set \(B\) {{c1::dominates (denoted \(A \preceq B\))}} if {{c2::there exists an injective function \(A \rightarrow B\).}}
Example: \(f(x): \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} = x\)
A set \(A\) is called countable if {{c1::\(A \preceq \mathbb{N}\)}}, and uncountable otherwise.
Is the set \(\{0,1\}^*\) (finite binary sequences) countable?
Yes. A possible injection to \(\mathbb{N}\) is to add a "1" at the beginning of each sequence and interpret it in binary.
Is the set \(\{0,1\}^\infty\) (semi-infinite binary sequences) countable?
No. This can be proven by Cantor's diagonalization argument.
\(a \mid b\) means that {{c1::\(a\) divides \(b\), that is, there exists a \(c \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that \(b = ac\)}}
\(\forall a \ne 0 \rightarrow a \mid 0\) and \(\forall a \quad 1 \mid a \land -1 \mid a\)
{{c1::\(a \mod m\)}} is the same as {{c2::\(R_m(a)\)}}
\(a  \equiv_m b \stackrel{\text{def}}{\iff}\) {{c1::\(m \mid (a-b)\)}}
The equation \(ax \equiv_m 1\) has a unique solution \(x \in \mathbb{Z}_m\) if and only if {{c1::\(\gcd(a,m) = 1\).}} This \(x\) is then called the multiplicative inverse of \(a \mod m\).

The direct product of \(n\) groups \(\langle G_1; *_1 \rangle, \ldots, \langle G_n; *_n \rangle\) is {{c1::the algebra \(\langle G_1 \times \cdots \times G_n; \star\rangle\)}}. The operation \(\star\) is component-wise.
A subgroup \(H\) of a group \(G\) is {{c1::a subset \(H \subseteq G\) which is a group in itself (closed with respect to all operations).}}
Trivial subgroups: \(\{e\}, G\)
The order of an element \(a\) in a group (denoted \(\text{ord}(a)\)) is {{c1::the smallest \(m \ge 1\) such that \(a^m = e\). If such an \(m\) does not exist, \(\text{ord}(a) = \infty\)}}
\(\text{ord}(e) = 1\) in any group
For a finite group \(G\), we call \(|G|\) the {{c1::order of \(G\)}}.
A group \(G = \langle g \rangle\) generated by an element \(g \in G\) is called {{c1::cyclic}}, and \(g\) is called {{c1::a generator of \(G\)}}.
If \(G\) is a finite group and \(H\) is a subgroup, then {{c1::the order of \(H\) divides the order of \(G\), i.e. \(|H|\) divides \(|G|\).}}
The group \(\mathbb{Z}^*_m\) contains all numbers \(a \in \mathbb{Z}_m\) that are {{c1::coprime to \(m\), that is, \(\gcd(a,m) = 1\).}}
The Euler function \(\varphi: \mathbb{Z}^+ \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}^+\) is defined as {{c1::the cardinality of \(\mathbb{Z}^*_m\).}}
In graph theory, a {{c1::walk (Weg)}} is a {{c2::series of connected vertices}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::path (Pfad)}} is a {{c1::walk without repeated vertices}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::closed walk (Zyklus)}} is a {{c1::walk where \(v_0 = v_n\) (start = end)}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::cycle (Kreis)}} is a {{c1::closed walk without repeated vertices}}.
In graph theory, an {{c2::Eulerian trail (misleadingly also called Eulerian path)}} is a {{c1::walk that visits each edge of the graph once}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::Hamilton path}} is a {{c1::path that visits each vertex of the graph once}}.

{{c1::A ring \(\langle R, +, -, 0, \cdot, 1 \rangle\)}} is an algebra with the properties that
{{c2::* \(\langle R, +, -, 0 \rangle\) is a commutative group}}
{{c3::* \(\langle R, \cdot, 1 \rangle\) is a monoid}}
{{c4::* \( a(b+c) = (ab) + (ac), (b+c)a = (ba) + (ca)\) (left and right distributive laws)}}
Examples: \(\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{R}\)
A ring is called {{c1::commutative}} if {{c2::\(ab = ba\).}}
An element \(u\) of a ring is called a {{c1::unit}} if \(u\) {{c2::is invertible, so \(uu^{-1} = u^{-1}u = 1\).}}
Example: Units of \(\mathbb{Z}\) are \(-1, 1\)
The set of units of \(R\) is denoted by {{c1::\(R^*\)}}
An {{c1::integral domain}} is a {{c2::commutative ring without zerodivisors (\( \forall a \ \forall b \quad ab = 0 \rightarrow a = 0 \lor b = 0\) ).}}

Examples: \(\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{R}\)
Counterexample: \(\mathbb{Z}_m, m\) not prime
A {{c1::field (Krper)}} is {{c2::a nontrivial commutative ring \(F\) in which every nonzero element is a unit, so \(F^* = F \backslash \{0\}\)}}
Example: \(\mathbb{R}\), but not \(\mathbb{Z}\)
\(\mathbb{Z}_p\) is a field if and only if {{c1::\(p\) is prime.}}
A {{c1::root (also: zero)}} of \(a(x) \in \mathbb{R}[x]\) is {{c2::an element \(y \in \mathbb{R}\) for which \(a(y) = 0\).}}
Example: \(x^4 + x^3 + x + 1\) in GF(2)\([x]\) has root 1.
In a field F, \(y \in F\) is a root of \(a(x)\) if and only if {{c1::\(x - y\) divides \(a(x)\).}}
The idea of {{c2::Universal Instantiation}} is that {{c1::if a statement is true for all elements, it is also true for a particular element, so \(\forall x F \models F[x/t]\).}}
Example: All elements in \(\mathbb{R}\) are invertible. Thus, 2 is also invertible.
Predicate logic: A formula in {{c2::prenex form}} has {{c1::all quantifiers in front and none afterwards. }}

DFS

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| + |V|) \)}}

Approach: {{c2::Explore as far as possible along each branch before backtracking. Potentially keep track of pre- / post-numbers to make edge classifications.}}

Uses: {{c3::Detect cycles (if backward edge), path finding, topological sorting, test if bipartite, mazes, ...}}

BFS

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| + |V|) \)}}

Approach: {{c2::First go through all direct successors of an edge, then move to a level deeper.}}

Uses: {{c3::Shortest path in unweighted graphs, cycle detection, test if graph is bipartite, path finding}}

Dijkstra

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}((|E| + |V|) \cdot \log|V|) \)}}

Approach: {{c2::Put the starting node into the queue, take it out, and set the distance for all adjacent nodes and put them into the queue. Repeat, update distances and only put nodes into the queue if they weren't visited before.}}

Uses: {{c3::Minimal-cost paths in non-negative weighted directed graphs}}

Bellman-Ford

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| \cdot |V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c2::Initiate all distances with \(\infty\). Then go \(|V| - 1\) times through every edge, and test for all (u,v) in E if \(\text{dist}[v] > \text{dist}[u] + w(u,v)\). If yes, update the distance. If after \(|V| - 1\) iterations an edge can still be relaxed (in a last iteration), then there exists a negative cycle.}}

Uses: {{c3::Detect negative cycles, find minimal-cost paths in weighted graphs with negative weights}}

Boruvka

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}((|E| + |V|) \cdot \log |V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c2::Add all vertices to the set of components (so every vertex has its own component). As long as the size of the components set is greater than 1, connect each component to the one with the cheapest edge.}}

Uses: {{c3::Find MST in weighted, undirected graph}}

Kruskal

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| \log |E| + |E| \log|V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c2::Sort the edges by weight and add them one-by-one as long as they are in different components (which can be checked efficiently with Union Find).}}

Uses: {{c3::Find MST in weighted, undirected graph}}

Prim

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}((|E| + |V|) \cdot \log|V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c2::We start at a given vertex. To this subtree we add one-by-one the cheapest edge connecting the subtree to another component until all vertices are connected. The implementation is very similar to Dijkstra.}}

Uses: {{c3::Find MST in weighted, undirected graph}}

Floyd-Warshall

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|V|^3)\)}}

Approach: {{c2::3D DP: It is based on a triple-nested for-loop with the following recursion: \(d[u][v] = \min(d[u][v], d[u][i] + d[i][v])\).}}

Uses: {{c3::All-to-all shortest path in directed graph without negative cycles.}}

Johnson

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| \cdot |V| + |V|^2 \cdot \log|V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c2::Idea: Make all edges positive and then perform Dijkstra \(n\) times. To do this, create an additional node that is linked to each node with edge weight 0 and store for each node a height \(h(x)\), where \(h(x)\) is equal to the shortest path from the new node n to the node x (might be negative). The new weights are calculated with \(w'(u,v) = w(u,v) + h(u) - h(v)\).}}

Uses: {{c3::All-to-all shortest paths in directed graphs without negative cycles.}}
A graph \(G = (V,E)\) is k-connected (k-zusammenhngend) if {{c1::you need to remove at least \(k\) vertices from the graph such that it becomes disconnected.}}
This graph is 2-connected. We need to remove 2 vertices to make the graph disconnected.
A graph \(G=(V,E)\) is \(k\)-edge-connected (k-kanten-zusammenhngend) if {{c1::we need to remove at least \(k\) edges from \(G\) such that it becomes disconnected.}}
This graph is 2-edge-connected, we must remove 2 edges to make it disconnected.
A \(u\)-\(v\)-separator is {{c1::a set \(X\) of vertices such that \(u, v\) are in different components after we remove these edges from \(G\), so in \(G[V \ \backslash \ X]\).}}
\(G = (V,E)\) is \(k\)-connected iff \(|V| \ge k + 1\) (otherwise not sensible) and every \(u\)-\(v\)-separator has {{c1::size \(|X| \ge k\).}}

(Menger's theorem)
{{c2::Every \(u\)-\(v\)-separator \(X\) has size \(|X| \ge k\) }} \(\iff\) {{c1::There exist \(k\) internally vertex-disjoint paths (i.e. they share no vertices) between \(u, v\).}}
(generalized by the max-flow min-cut theorem)
atomic
A statement / instruction is (truly) atomic if it is executed in a single, non-interruptible step by the CPU
Amdahls's law
Specifies the maximum amount of speedup that can be achieved for a program with a given sequential part. The pessimistic view on scalability.
bad interleaving
An interleaving that yields a problematic or otherwise undesirable computation, e.g. an incorrect result, a deadlock or non-deterministic output
busy waiting

A thread busily / actively waits, e.g. by spinning in a loop, for a condition to be true. (as opposed to sleeping)
Trade-off: busy waiting uses up CPU time, whereas blocking may cause additional context switches.
concurrency

Dealing with multiple things at the same time (as opposed to parallelism: doing multiple things at the same time). Reasoning about and managing shared resources. Often used interchangeably with parallelism.
context switch

Switching a CPU from one computation to another. Usually for switching between processes, but can also refer to switching between threads. Incurs a context switch overhead (that is large for processes, small for threads)
critical section
A piece of code that may only be executed by one thread at a time to guarantee correctness.
data race

A program has a data race if, at any point, a memory location could be written from one thread, whilst concurrently being read or written from another thread. (often used interchangably with race condition)
divide and conquer style parallelism

Solve problems by recursively solving smaller sub-problems and combining them. You can solve the sub-problems in separate threads to parallelize effectively. These sub-problems can often be efficiently scheduled (less variety in task load).
deadlock
Circular waiting/blocking (no instructions are executed/CPU time used) between treads, so that the system cannot make any progress anymore.
Gustafson's law
Specifies how much more work can be performed for a given amount of time by adding more processors. The optimistic view on scalability.
instruction level parallelism (ILP)
CPU-internal parallelisation of independent instructions, with the goal of improving performance by increasing utilisation of the functional units.
latency
Evaluation metric for pipelines. Latency measures the time a pipeline needs to process a given work item (e.g. a CPU instruction)
livelock
A situation in which all threads starve by repeteadly trying to enter a critical section, but never succeeding. Similar to a deadlock - no real progress in the system.
liveness property
Property of a system: "something good eventually happens". Can only be violated in infinite time. Infinite loops & starvation are typical safety properties.
lock

A lock on a token/resource. Usually provided by a programming language to enforce mutual exclusion by protecting a critical section. A lock can be acquired by a thread and is then held until it is released.

In Java, every object can be used as a lock (intrinsic/monitor lock), but the JDK also provides more complex locks.
lockout
Needlessly preventing a thread from entering a critical section
mutual exclusion
Prevention of multiple threads being in a critical section at the same time
multiprocessing (multitasking)
Concurrent execution of multiple tasks/processes, typically refers to parallelism on the operating system level
multithreading
Threads running in parallel
parallelism
Doing multiple things at the same time (as opposed to concurrency: dealing with multiple things at the same time)
parallel execution time, \(T_p, T_\infty\)

\(T_p\): time required to perform some work on \(p\) processors
\(T_\infty\): time required for some work if we had infinite processors (total runtime only depends on sequential part)
process
Independently running instance of a program/application, typically on the OS level. Similar to a thread, but usually more heavy-weight and encapsulated in memory.
process context

All state associated with a process, including CPU state (registers, program counter), program state (stack, heap, resource handles) and additional management information. 

A thread also has (much smaller) context
race condition

A program has a race condition if at any point its results / output may change if events happen in different order. (events could be scheduling, network delays, etc.)

Often used interchangeable with data race.
A lock is reentrant if {{c1::it can be acquired / released multiple times by the same thread.}}
If a lock is non-reentrant, when trying to acquire it again exceptions or other problems might occur.
What are typical safety properties?
Exceptions, absence of deadlocks and mutual exclusions
sequential execution time, \(T_1\)
\(T_1\): The time that is required to perform some work on a single processor
sequential cutoff
When decomposing work, stop splitting tasks at a given problem size (sequential cutoff). Problem size should be significantly larger than scheduling overhead
sequential part
Part of a given program that can't be executed in parallel. Limits the maximum speedup.
scheduler

management process that peforms context switches and selects next processes / threads to run

Schedulers usually not give any guarantees when / how they act
scheduling overhead
extra time spent by the system or the algorithm to distribute work on multiple threads/tasks
shared resource
any resource (memory location, input / output) shared by multiple threads
speedup, \(S_p\)

\(S_p\): How much faster a program runs using \(p\) processors, compared to the sequential version. \(S_p = \frac{T_1}{T_p}\)

Speedup is an absolute value; the relative value is efficiency
A thread starves if {{c1::it can never enter a critical section}}.
synchronisation
Some form of orchestration via threads, usually for preventing bad interleavings
synchronised (keyword)
Java keyword enforcing mutual exclusion for a critical section via some object's intrinsic lock
task graph, work, span

Graph (DAG) created by nodes (tasks) and edges (spawns, joins).
Work (\(T_1\)) in a task graph: sum of the cost of all nodes in the graph
Span (\(T_\infty\)) in a task graph: Critical path / height of the task graph
throughput
evaluation metric for pipelines. amount of work that can be done by a pipeline in a given period of time
thread

Independent unit of computation that executes a piece of code. The concept of threads exists on
* hardware (CPU)
* OS
* programming language
level.
thread mapping

How a Java thread maps to an OS thread. 
Native threading: JVM thread one-to-one mapped to OS thread
Green threading: JVM threads multiple-to-one mapped to OS thread
vectorisation
special machine code instructions to perform an operation to a bigger chunk of data (SIMD)
work partitioning
splitting a program into smaller tasks for parallelization. Ideally, every task performs work independently

{{c3::Die geometrische Reihe}} konvergiert fr \(|q| < 1\):

{{c1::\(\sum_{k=0}^\infty q^k\)}} \(=\) {{c2::\(\frac{1}{1-q}\)}}
Die harmonische Reihe \(\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n}\) {{c1::divergiert.}}
In a one-hot encoding, all {{c1::values are low (0) except one (1)}}.
Advantage: reduces next-state logic
In a binary encoding, {{c1::each state is represented as a binary number.}}

Advantage: very compact, reduces amount of Flip-Flops used for state
Disadvantage: other logic more complicated
In an Output encoding, {{c1::outputs are directly accessible in state encoding.}}

Example: 001, 010, 100, 110 for a (green, yellow, red) traffic light
Advantage: minimizes output logic
What is the big limitation of Output Encodings for FSMs?
They only work for Moore machines, but not for Mealy ones.
interlocking
Detecting dependencies between instructions for pipelining. Can be done in hardware or software
R-type instructions operate on {{c1::three registers}}
Examples: add, and, slt
I-type instructions operate on {{c1::two registers and a 16-bit immediate.}}
Examples: addi, lw, beq
J-type instructions operate on {{c1::one 26-bit immediate.}}
Examples: j, jal
In Boolean algebra, \(\bullet\) means {{c1::AND}}.
In Boolean algebra, \(+\) means {{c1::OR}}.
Ein Graph ist \(k\)-zusammenhngend, wenn {{c1::wir mindestens \(k\) Knoten lschen mssen, damit er nicht mehr zusammenhngend ist.}}
Wenn ein Graph \(k\)-zusammenhngend ist, ist er auch {{c1::\(k-1\)-zusammenhngend.}}
Es gibt {{c1::\(n^k\)}} Mglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente geordnet mit Zurcklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) zu ziehen.
Es gibt {{c1::\(\frac{n!}{(n-k)!}\)}} Mglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente geordnet ohne Zurcklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) Elementen zu ziehen.
Es gibt {{c1::\(\binom{n+k-1}{k}\)}} Mglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente ungeordnet mit Zurcklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) Elementen zu ziehen.
Es gibt {{c1::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}} Mglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente ungeordnet ohne Zurcklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) Elementen zu ziehen.
Ein induzierter Teilgraph entsteht, wenn man aus einem Graph {{c1::nur Knoten & dessen verbundene Kanten entfernt. }} Man darf also nicht {{c1::nur Kanten entfernen}}.

Das leere Wort in einem Alphabet \(\Sigma\) wird mit {{c1::\(\lambda\)}} bezeichnet.
The order of the differential equation is {{c1::the order of the highest derivative in the equation}}.
A differential equation is called homogenous if {{c1::its right hand side is 0}}.

Ein deterministischer endlicher Automat (EA) ist ein Tupel \(M = (Q, \Sigma, \delta, q_0, F)\) wobei
  • Q {{c1::eine endliche Menge von Zustnden}}
  • \(\Sigma\) {{c2::ein Eingabealphabet}}
  • \(q_0 \in Q\) {{c3::der Anfangszustand}}
  • \(\delta : Q \times \Sigma \to Q\) {{c4::die bergangsfunktion}}
  • \(F \subseteq Q\) {{c5::die Menge der akzeptierenden Zustnde}}
ist.
\(\delta(q,a) = p\) bedeutet, {{c1::dass \(M\) in den Zustand \(p\) bergeht, falls \(M\) im Zustand \(q\) das Symbol \(a\) gelesen hat}}
Die Klasse der regulren Sprachen \(\mathcal{L}_{EA}\) ist die Klasse der Sprachen, {{c1::welche von einem endlichen Automaten akzeptiert werden.}}
Jede Sprache \(L \in \mathcal{L}_{EA}\) wird regulr genannt.
A useful equation for avoiding cancellation is \(a - b = \) {{c1::\(\frac{a^2 - b^2}{a+b}\)}}
A useful equation for avoiding cancellation is \(\log a - \log b = \) {{c1::\(\log \frac{a}{b}\)}}
A trap is {{c1::an intentional synchronous exception}}.
Examples: syscalls, special instructions
A fault is an {{c1::unintential but potentially recoverable synchronous}} exception.
Examples: page faults, floating point exceptions
An abort is an {{c1::unintentional and unrecoverable}} exception.
Example: division by 0, machine check
An interrupt is an {{c1::asychronous signal from an I/O device}}.
A page fault happens when {{c1::a user accesses a location in memory that is not in physical memory}}.
Afterwards: returns to faulting instruction
If an interrupt is maskable, we can {{c1::choose to ignore or delay it}}.
IOMMU stands for {{c1::I/O Memory Management Unit}}.

Der Satz von Cook besagt, dass {{c1::SAT NP-vollstndig ist.}}
Eine Grammatik ist eine Typ-3-Grammatik (regulr), falls {{c1::\(\forall (\alpha,\beta) \in P: \alpha \in \Sigma_N, \beta \in \Sigma_T^* \times \Sigma_N \cup \Sigma_T^*\).}}
d.h. nur ein Nichtterminal und Terminale nur als Prefix
Eine Grammatik ist eine Typ-2-Grammatik (kontextfrei), falls {{c1::\(\forall (\alpha, \beta) \in P: \alpha \in \Sigma_N, \beta \in (\Sigma_N \cup \Sigma_T)^*\).}}
Eine Grammatik ist eine Typ-1-Grammatik (kontextsensitiv), falls {{c1::\(\forall (\alpha, \beta) \in P: |\alpha| \le |\beta|\).}}
d.h. kann nicht "schrumpfen"
Der Satz von Rice besagt, dass {{c1::jedes semantisch nichttriviale Entscheidungsproblem ber Turingmaschinen unentscheidbar ist.}}

semantisch: unabhngig von Struktur der TM
nichttrivial: mindestens 1 aber nicht alle TM sind in der Sprache

Eine Sprache \(L\) ist NP-vollstndig, falls {{c1::\(L \in\) NP und \(L\) NP-schwer ist.}}
z.B. SAT

In scheduling, priority inversion is {{c1::a problem where a low-priority task holds a lock that a high-priority task needs. Then a middle-priority task gets scheduled instead, and the high-priority task is unable to run.}}
This happened on the Mars Pathfinder rover.
A preemptive scheduler may {{c1::interrupt and suspend a task before it is completed.}}
In scheduling, priority inheritance is {{c1::a solution to the priority inversion problem. If a task holds a lock, it temporarily has the priority of the highest process waiting for the lock.}}
This requires the scheduler to be involved in lock operations.
In scheduling, priority ceiling is {{c1::a solution to the priority inversion problem. If a task holds a lock, it temporarily has the priority of the highest process which can ever hold the lock.}}
This can require static analysis of the entire system.
The Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation is used to determine the {{c1::reversal potential across a membrane including all permeable ions.}}
An afferent neuron/axon conducts action potentials {{c1::from the periphery towards the CNS}}.
An efferent neuron/axon conducts action potentials {{c1::away from the CNS to the periphery.}}

The Nodes of Ranvier are {{c1::myelin-sheath gaps along the axon where the action potential is regenerated}}.
The meninges are {{c1::the three membranes that surround and protect the brain / spinal cord}}.

The arachnoid mater is {{c1::the thin middle layer of the meninges}}.
Among other things, it keeps blood from getting into the cerebrospinal fluid.
The pia mater is {{c1::the thin innermost layer of the meninges}}.
Among other things, it prevents cerebrospinal fluid from reaching the brain.

Bootstrapping (also called booting) is the process {{c1::of starting the operating system when the machine is powered on / reset}}. It ends when {{c1::the operating system is running regular processes}}.

A computer boots by doing four steps:
  1. {{c1::CPU starts executing code at a fixed address, where the Boot ROM is.}}
  2. {{c2::The Boot ROM code loads the second stage boot loader into RAM.}}
  3. {{c3::The second stage boot loader loads the kernel and (sometimes) an initial file system into RAM.}}
  4. {{c4::Jump to the kernel entry point.}}
In user mode, we have {{c1::limited}} privileges.
e.g. we cannot write to any memory
We switch from user mode to kernel mode when {{c1::a processor exception happens (e.g. a syscall trap or a page fault)}}.

When an exception occurs, we
  1. {{c1::Finish executing the current instruction}}.
  2. {{c2::Switch to kernel mode}}
  3. {{c3::Look up exception cause in the exception vector table}}
  4. {{c4::Jump to the address from the table}}
A synchronous exception happens because {{c1::we execute an instruction}}.
The kernel is {{c1::the code that runs in kernel mode}}.
A system library is {{c1::a convenient interface to the kernel}}.
A daemon is {{c1::a user-space process which provides OS services}}.
Example: crond for repeating tasks
IPC stands for {{c1::Inter-Process Communication}}.
A hardware timer regularly {{c1::causes an interrupt that returns control to the kernel handler}}.
Homonyms are {{c1::the same name being bound to different objects}}.
While the interrupt handler runs, interrupts {{c1::are turned off}}.
Useful for implementing atomic operations
A process is {{c1::the execution of a program with restricted rights}}.
A thread is {{c1::a sequence of instructions within a process}}.
The name of a process is {{c1::its PID}}.
The Process Control Block (PCB) is a {{c1::data structure holding information about a process}}.
There are two main approaches for creating a process: {{c1::spawn}} and {{c2::fork/exec}}.
Fill in the missing process state / transition.
Fill in the missing process state / transition.
The trap frame contains {{c1::values of certain registers saved there before a syscall is handled}}.
The kernel switches processes when either {{c1::a timer interrupts it}} or when {{c1::a process blocks}}.
One of the main purposes of the init process is to {{c1::wait for any child to exit() so that there are no orphans}}.
The two ways for processes to communicate are through {{c1::message passing}} or through {{c2::shared memory}}.
Marshalling is {{c1::the process of converting data into a format suitable for transmission}}.
e.g. arguments in a RPC are marshalled.

A zombie process has to continue to exist because {{c1::the exit status must be preserved}}.

We need only three concepts to build all OS structures:
  • {{c1::Mode switch}}

Uniprocessor scheduling is {{c1::the problem of scheduling tasks on a single processor core}}.
Batch scheduling is {{c1::the problem of scheduling a (potentially unbounded) set of finite tasks}}.
The execution time (or run time) of a job is {{c1::the time it takes for the job to execute once started}}.
The hold time of a job is {{c1::the time it takes for the job from arriving at the scheduler to start executing}}.
The wait time of a job is {{c1::the total time it takes from arriving to finishing the job}}.
hold time + execution time
The arrival time (or release time) of a job is {{c1::the time where it arrives at the scheduler}}.
In scheduling, First Come First Served (FCFS) works by always dispatching the job {{c1::with the earliest arrival time.}}
The convoy phenomenon is a problem in scheduling where {{c1::many short jobs are stalled because of a long-running job, which inflates mean wait times}}.
Multi-level feedback queues is a class of scheduling algorithms that {{c1::penalize CPU-bound tasks in favor of I/O-bound tasks}}.
The aim of multi-level feedback queue algorithms is to {{c1::get good response times for interactive jobs and good throughput for background jobs}}.
In scheduling, Earliest Deadline First works by dispatching the job that {{c1::has the earliest deadline}}.
Would be implemented with a Priority Queue to work in \(\mathcal{O}(\log n)\)
Reservation-based scheduling guarantees {{c1::a minimum amount of CPU time to each job.}}
A scheduler is work conserving if {{c1::no processor is ever idle when there is a runnable task.}}
The First-level Interrupt Service Routine (FLISR) is {{c1::the code that executes immediately as a result of a (device) interrupt}}.
A character device is used for {{c1::unstructured}} IO and we access {{c1::single bytes in a byte-stream}}.
A block device is used for {{c1::structured}} IO and we access {{c1::whole blocks, e.g. disk blocks}}.
The Process Control Block must contain at least {{c1::the page table, trap frame, kernel stack, open files, program name, scheduling state, PID}}.

Affinity scheduling is the idea that {{c1::we should schedule jobs on the same core as much as possible}}.
A deferred procedure call (DPC, also known as soft interrupt handler) is {{c1::a program created by the first-level interrupt handler to handle a device interrupt}}.
With base and limit registers, programs had to be compiled to {{c1::position-independent code}} because {{c1::the base address is not known at compile time}}.
(unless relocation registers were used)
A disadvantage of relocation registers is that they do not allow {{c1::sharing code / data}}.
With segmentation, each process has a {{c1::segment table containing segments (offset + size)}}.
An advantage of segmentation for MMU is that we can {{c1::share code/data between processes}}.
A disadvantage of segmentation for MMU is {{c1::external fragmentation - wasted space}}.
With zero-on-reference, we {{c1::zero the memory when allocated}} to avoid {{c2::leaking information}}.
With fill-on-demand, we can {{c2::start a program before its code is in physical memory}} by {{c1::bringing in pages from disk when needed}}.
Copy-on-write (COW) optimizes {{c1::copying large regions of virtual memory}}.
When calling fork() with Copy-on-write, we {{c1::copy the page table and set all mappings to read-only in both address spaces}}.
When we write to a read-only page with copy-on-write, we {{c1::allocate a new page, copy the contents, and change the mapping to the new page}}.
Bldy's Anomaly is the anomaly that {{c1::for some replacement algorithms increasing cache size can reduce the hit rate for certain access patterns}}.
e.g. FIFO has this anomaly
The clock (or second chance) replacement policy approximates {{c1::LRU}}, but {{c2::is much cheaper}}.
A security principal or subject is {{c1::an entity to which we give access rights}}.

An access control list (ACL) is a {{c1::list for a column of the access control list, so a set of the rights principals have over an object}}.
Cranial nerves are the nerves {{c1::emerging directly from the brain}} and connect to {{c2::our primary senses (vision / taste / smell / hearing)}}.
The ventricular system is {{c1::a set of four holes (cerebral ventricles) in the brain}}. In there {{c2::the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)}} is produced.
The basal ganglia is a {{c1::part of the brain that is (among other things) involved in voluntary movement}}.
The thalamus is a {{c1::large mass of gray matter that also acts as a relay for sensory signals}}.
The hypothalamus is {{c1::a part of the brain that connects the nervous system to the hormone system}}.
The cerebellum ("little brain") is a {{c1::part of the brain that is important for motor control}}.
Camillo Golgi discovered a {{c1::technique to stain neurons in nervous tissue}}.
Hodgkin and Huxley were able to {{c1::describe how ionic currents caused the action potential}}.
When neurotransmitter vesicles undergo priming, {{c2::they become ready to be released}}. This corresponds to {{c1::the assembly of the SNARE complex}}.
SNARE complexes are {{c1::protein structures which help with vesicle priming & fusion}}.
Hebb's law says that {{c1::neurons that fire together, wire together}}.
The axon hillock is the {{c1::part of the soma that connects to the axon}}.
In the axon hillock, {{c1::potentials are summed and if a threshold is exceeded, an action potential propagates through the axon}}.
When the action potential arrives at the presynaptic terminal, {{c2::voltage-gated \(Ca^{2+}\) channels are opened}}, which cause {{c1::neurotransmitter to be released}}.
Long-term potentiation (LTP) is {{c1::a strengthening of synapses}} and happens {{c2::after short but high-frequency stimulation}}.
Long Term Depression (LTD) is {{c2::a weakening of synapses}} and happens after {{c1::long but low frequency stimulation}}.
A Hopfield network consists of {{c1::multiple McCulloch-Pitts neurons that are fully connected}}.
The receptor {{c1::NMDA}} is critically involved in Long-Term Potentiation.
Population codes are {{c1::neural representations at the level of groups of cells}}.
The association cortex is the part of the cerebral cortex that is {{c1::not involved in sensory / motor processing}}.
Potassium is a chemical element called {{c1::Kalium}} in German.
Sodium is a chemical element called {{c1::Natrium}} in German.
In an asynchronous environment, a message will {{c1::arrive in a finite but unbounded time}}.
Any-Input validity says that {{c1::the decision value must be the input of any node}}.
All-Same Validity says that {{c1::if all nodes start with the same input, that must be the decision value}}.
A network with \(n\) nodes cannot reach byzantine agreement with {{c1:: \(f \ge \frac{n}{3}\)}} byzantine nodes.

The King algorithm has three phases:{{c1::
  1. Vote (broadcast value)
  2. Propose (if a value is received often, propose it)
  3. King (if few proposals, follow the king)
}}
In a distributed system, churn is {{c1::how much nodes are joining and leaving the system}}.
A quorum is a {{c1::subset of nodes of a system}}.
A quorum system is a {{c1::set of quorums such that every two quorums intersect}}.
In the Majority quorum system, {{c1::every quorum has \(\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\rfloor +1\)  nodes}}.
An access strategy \(Z\) defines {{c1::the probability \(P_Z(Q)\)  of accessing a quorum \(Q \in S\)  such that \(\sum_{Q\in S}P_Z(Q) = 1\) .}}
The work of a quorum is {{c1::the number of nodes in it}}.
The resilience of a quorum system is {{c1::the largest number of nodes that can fail such that there's always a quorum without failed nodes}}.
Every quorum system has a load of at least {{c1::\(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n} }\)}}.
A uniform quorum system is one in which {{c1::all quorums have the same number of nodes}}.
The load in a (B-)grid quorum system is {{c1::\(\Theta(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n} })\), which is optimal}}.
The Precise Time Protocol (PTP) is similar to NTP, but {{c1::uses MAC layer timestamps}}.

A logical volume can {{c1::merge multiple physical devices into a single volume}}.

Fast, but cannot run arbitrary OS binaries
Virtualization with binary rewriting {{c1::patches the kernel on the fly to remove unvirtualizable instructions}}.

A strategy profile is a social optimum if it {{c1::minimizes the sum of all costs (or maximizes payoff)}}.

Braess's paradox says that {{c1::adding one or more roads to a road network can slow down overall traffic flow}}.

A transaction with a timelock is {{c1::not released into the network until the timelock expires}}.
The diameter of a graph is the {{c1::longest shortest path}}.
The span of a set of vectors is {{c1::the set of all possible linear combinations of them}}.
The span is a linear subspace.
The p-norm of a vector \(x \in \mathbb{R}^n\) is defined as {{c1::\(||x||_p=\left(\sum_{i=1}^n |x_i|^p\right)^{1/p}\)}}.

The conditions the caller of a method must fullfill.

The guarantees provided to the caller after executing the method, given the caller satisfied the precondition.

CFG stands for {{c1::Control Flow Graph}}

An intraprocedural CFG of a procedure \(p\) is a graph (\(N\),\(E\)) where:
  • N is the set of {{c2::basic blocks in \(p\) plus designated entry and exit blocks}}
  • E contains
    • an edge from \(a\) to \(b\) with condition \(c\) iff {{c1::the execution of the basic block \(a\) is succeeded by the execution of \(b\) if the condition \(c\) holds}}
    • an edge (entry, \(a\), true) if {{c3::\(a\) is the first basic block of \(p\)}}
    • edges (\(b\), exit, true) {{c4::for each basic block \(b\) that ends with a return statement}}
Statement coverage is {{c1::how many of the statements were executed}}
Branch coverage tests {{c1::all the possible branches in the control flow}}
Branch coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\text{Number of executed branches} }{\text{Total number of branches} }\)}}
Statement coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\text{Number of executed statements} }{\text{Total number of statements} }\)}}
Branch coverage leads to {{c1::more}} thorough testing than statement coverage
Path coverage tests {{c1::all possible paths through the CFG}}
Path coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\text{Number of executed paths} }{\text{Total number of paths} }\)}}
Path coverage leads to {{c1::more}} thorough testing than both statement and branch coverage
Loop coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\binom{\text{Number of executed loops} }{\text{with 0,1 and more than 1 iterations} } }{\text{Total number of loops * 3} }\)}}
In loop coverage, for each loop, test {{c1::zero, one and more than one consecutive iterations}}
An advantage of holding out less data (smaller test set) is that we are {{c1::more likely to get a better model}}.
An advantage of holding out more data (larger test set) is that we are {{c1::able to better estimate the generalization error}}.
The training set is used to {{c1::find the best parameters of a given method}}.
The validation set is used to {{c1::find the best method}}.
The test set is used to {{c1::check how good our model performs}}.

Statement coverage leads to {{c1::less}} thorough testing than branch coverage
Statement and branch coverage lead to {{c1::less}} thorough testing than path coverage

We have a symbolic state per {{c1::program point}}

1. Start with an initial symbolic state
  2. Propagate this across all statements, i.e. symbolically execute the program
  3. Duplicate the current state at branch points: one copy per branch
  4. When following a branch, add the corresponding condition to the state
  5. Eventually, well have a final state per path
  6. Per final state, solve the path conditions to obtain test inputs that exercise the path

In linear temporal logic the \(\phi\) symbol denotes {{c1::what holds now}}

(F = finally)
In linear temporal logic \(G\phi\) or \(\square\phi\) denotes {{c1::that \(\phi\) always holds}}
(G = globally)

Weakly-typed languages do {{c1::classify values into types}}, but do not {{c1::enforce additional restrictions}}.
Strongly-typed languages enforce that {{c1::all arguments to an operation have the correct types}}.
A type is a {{c1::set of values sharing some properties}}.
In static type checking, we determine {{c1::at compile time}} if a program is correctly typed.
In dynamic type checking, we determine {{c1::at run time}} if the arguments to an operation are of the expected type.
The type invariant for statically type-safe OOP language is "{{c1::In every program state, the value of the variable v is an element of the declared type of v.}}"

Duck typing is an informal name for {{c1::structural dynamic type systems}}.

In every iteration of insertion sort, we {{c1::take the first element from the unsorted input and place it correctly in the sorted output}}.

An overriding method must {{c1::not require more specific}} parameter types than the method it overrides.

An overriding method must {{c1::not have a more general}} result type than the method it overrides.

(since fields are bound statically)
The disadvantage of arrays being covariant in Java and C# is that {{c1::each array write requires a run-time type check}}.
An object structure is a {{c1::set of objects that are connected via references}}.

In bytecode type checking, every instruction is considered {{c1::at most once (never if error before)::amount}}.
When using the bytecode type inference algorithm, all interfaces are {{c1::treated as Object}} because the {{c2::smallest common supertype (SCS) may not be well-defined}}.

In Scala, if a generic type is annotated with +, it is made {{c1::covariant}}.
The covariance annotation for generics is useful (and usable) when the type variable only occurs as {{c1::a result type or a type of an immutable field}}.
The contravariance annotation for generics is useful (and usable) if the type variable only occurs in {{c1::a parameter type}}.

A user-centered approach is characterized by
  • {{c1::early focus on users and tasks}}
  • {{c2::empirical measurement}}
  • {{c3::iterative design}}
Formative methods help us understand {{c1::the problem and our users to inform our design}}
Evaluative methods help us understand {{c1::how well our design works}}

Five important needfinding methods are
  • {{c1::Interview}}
  • {{c2::Diary Study}}
  • {{c3::Retrospective Survey}}
  • {{c4::Artifact Analysis}}
  • {{c5::Contextual Inquiry}}

The Design Thinking Process has five steps:
  1. {{c1::Empathize}}
  2. {{c2::Define}}
  3. {{c3::Ideate}}
  4. {{c4::Prototype}}
  5. {{c5::Test}}
In a diary study, we ask users to {{c1::record events when they happen}}.

Diary studies are useful for cases where
  • {{c1::events are rare}}
  • {{c2::events are easily forgotten}}
  • {{c3::the frequency of the event is important}}
The disadvantage of diary studies is that {{c1::people change their behavior when they track themselves}}.
In a Retrospective Survey, we ask a user about {{c1::an event that happened in the past}}.

Retrospective Surveys are a good fit for
  • {{c1::rare but important events}}
  • {{c2::recent events}}
  • {{c3::memorable events}}
Retrospective Surveys don't work well for {{c1::non-memorable events}}.
In Artifact Analysis, we look at {{c1::artifacts users have created, e.g. documents or posts}}.
The disavantages of Artifact Analysis are that {{c1::it requires artifacts to be produced and it can be time-consuming}}.
In Contextual Enquiry, we {{c1::combine elements of the other needfinding methods and use them in the task environment::do what?}}.
Contextual Enquiry looks at what users {{c1::do}}.
Contextual Enquiry is more {{c1::objective}} than other methods of needfinding.
A vertical prototype implements {{c1::the critical path of one or few features}}.
A horizontal prototype implements {{c1::an overview with little to no functionality}}.

Examples of analytical methods are 
  • {{c1::usability/UX inspection methods}}
  • {{c2::design walkthroughs}}
  • {{c3::heuristic evaluations}}

Examples of empirical methods are
  • {{c1::Usability/UX tests}}
  • {{c2::Controlled experiments}}
  • {{c3::Case studies}}
In formative evaluation, mainly {{c1::qualitative}} data is collected.
(some quantitative data, e.g. user opinion in questionnaire)
Formative evaluation focuses mostly on what parts of the design are {{c1::not working}}.
Summative evaluations focus on what parts of the design are {{c1::working}}.
Usability is a part of {{c1::User Experience}}.
Analytical investigation is performed by {{c1::usability and domain experts}}.
The difference between UI inspections and cognitive walkthroughs is that in UI inspections we focus on {{c1::one aspect / element of a design}}.
The advantages of heuristic evaluations are that they are {{c1::cheap, fast and easy to use (even for inexperienced practitioners)}}.
The limitations of heuristic evaluation are that {{c1::it does not take a comprehensive view and experts might be held back by heuristics}}.
GOMS (model) stands for {{c1::Goals, Operators, Methods, Selection rules}}.
The Operators in the GOMS model are {{c1::the cognitive processes and physical actions needed to reach the goals}}.
e.g. click the mouse, press key
The three primary usability metrics are {{c1::effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction}}.
A Latin Square helps us {{c1::reduce the number of experimental orderings}}.
A p-value of 0.05 means that {{c1::assuming \(H_0\) is true, there is a 5% chance to obtain at least as extreme results we have obtained}}.
The Type I error is {{c1::the rejection of a true null hypothesis (false positive)}}.
defined by the \(\alpha\)-level
The Type II error is {{c1::the failure to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative)}}.
defined by the \(\beta\)-level
In an experiment, having independent samples means that {{c1::one subject was exposed to one condition (between-subject design)}}.
In an experiment, having dependent samples means that {{c1::one subject was exposed to all conditions (within-subject design)}}.
Non-parametric tests do {{c1::not assume a specific distribution, only equal spread of group samples::assume what?}}.
The disadvantage of non-parametric tests compared to parametric tests is that {{c1::they have less statistical power (higher chance of Type II errors)}}.
An example of a non-parametric test for two dependent measures is the {{c1::Wilcoxon signed-rank test}}.
An example of a non-parametric test for categorical data is the {{c1::Chi-Square test}}.
Parametric tests assume {{c1::Gaussian distribution and homoscedasticity (similar variances in groups)}}.
An example of a parametric test for one or two measures is the {{c1::t-test}}.
An example for a parametric test for multiple measures is the {{c1::ANOVA analysis}}.
To test if data is normally distributed, we can use the {{c1::Shapiro-Wilk test}}.
To test for homoscedasticity (similar variances), we can use the {{c1::Levene's test}}.
The Model Human Processor consists of three processors: {{c1::Perceptual, Cognitive and Motor}}.
Bloch's law states that for \(t < 100 \text{ms}\), {{c1::the response \(R = I \cdot t\) to a visual stimulus is constant}}.
Fitt's law says that movement time equals {{c1::\(a + b * \log_2(\frac{2D}{W})\), where \(a,b\) are device-/environment-specific constants, \(D\) is the distance and \(W\) is the target width}}.
The index of performance \(\text{IP}\) is defined as {{c1::\(\frac{\text{ID} }{\text{MT} }\), where \(\text{ID} = \log_2\frac{2D}{W}\) is the index of difficulty and \(\text{MT}\) is movement time}}.

The four key Gestalt principles are
  • {{c1::Emergence (brain derives meaning from chaos)}}
  • {{c2::Multistability (brain sees multiple interpretations)}}
  • {{c3::Reification (brain fills in the gaps)}}
  • {{c4::Invariance (brain is not confused by variations)}}
In Gestalt principles, the law of Closure states that {{c1::humans prefer to see complete figures and will perceive incomplete figures as whole}}.
Feature Integration Theory is a theory of {{c1::attention}}.
Feature Integration Theory proposes two stages for processing stimuli: {{c1::the preattentive stage and the focused attention stage}}.
In the first, preattentive stage of Feature Integration Theory, {{c1::we automatically create feature maps (color, orientation, intensity) of stimuli::what happens?}}.
In the second, focused attention stage of Feature Integration Theory, {{c1::we combine the feature maps to objects, which requires attention::what happens?}}.
Perceptual Load Theory suggests a potential resolution to the {{c1::early/late selection debate}}.

These eight factors determine input device effectiveness:
  • {{c1::Pointing speed}}
  • {{c2::Pointing precision}}
  • {{c3::Errors}}
  • {{c4::Time to learn}}
  • {{c5::Time to grasp}}
  • {{c6::User preference}}
  • {{c7::Desk footprint}}
  • {{c8::Cost}}

An input device can be represented as a six-tuple: \((M, \text{In}, S, R, \text{Out}, W)\):
  • {{c2::\(M\) - Manipulation operator}}
  • {{c3::\(\text{In}\) - Input domain}}
  • {{c4::\(S\) - Current state of device}}
  • {{c5::\(R\) - (Resolution) mapping from input to output domain}}
  • {{c6::\(\text{Out}\) - Output domain}}
  • \(W\) - Additional aspects (not relevant)
An isotonic input device is {{c1::movable (e.g. mouse)}}.
a trackpad is also isotonic because the finger is input device
An elastic input device is {{c1::movable, but goes back to a neutral position (e.g. joystick)}}.
An isometric input device is {{c1::immovable (e.g. Thinkpad nipple)}}.
For touch devices, we can significantly increase touch accuracy if we {{c1::know the user and the position of the device (3DOF)}}.
The idea of beam pruning is to {{c1::select the \(n\) most likely tokens and restrict the search space to tokens with these prefixes}}.
\(n\) is called beam size
A bigram is {{c1::a sequence of two tokens, usually characters}}.
Haptics is the {{c1::study of touch, force and tactile feedback in HCI}}.
Haptics can be divided into two categories: {{c1::Tactile}} and {{c2::Kinesthetic}}.

The limitations of vibrotactile limitations are:
  • {{c1::broad localization of the sensation}}
  • {{c2::superficial feedback}}
  • {{c3::the perception of the strength of vibration can vary}}
Tactile feedback is about {{c2::vibrations / textures}} while kinesthetic feedback is about {{c1::forces/proprioception}}.
Current limitation 1 of Haptics: {{c1::Kinesthetic haptic feedback}} is not common in user electronics.
Current limitation 2 in haptics: the {{c1::human state}} is not taken into account.
Current limitation 3 in haptics: current systems only react to {{c1::system states}}.
Current limitation 4 in haptics: we are limited to {{c1::vibrotactile feedback}}.
To overcome the current limitations of haptics, we need to enable sensing of {{c1::human state}}, and use that to {{c2::control the device intelligently}}.
Computational Rationality is {{c1::the study of computational principles of intelligence in living and artificial beings}}.
One reason that we want user models is that they {{c2::test if we understand interaction}}, which helps us {{c1::create and validate new HCI theories}}.

The Model Human Processor does not:
  • {{c4::learn}}
  • {{c3::adapt}}
  • {{c2::generalize}}
  • {{c1::model tradeoffs}}
Computational Rationality consists of two things: {{c1::Finding an optimal policy}} and {{c2::bound it to something human-like (Bounded Rationality)}}.
In reinforcement learning, when the agent takes an action \(A_t\), then the environment responds with {{c1::a state \(S_{t+1}\)and a reward \(R_{t+1}\)}}.

Reinforcement learning is different from other ML paradigms because
  • {{c1::There is no supervisor, only a reward signal}}
  • {{c2::Feedback is delayed}}
  • {{c3::Time matters (sequential, non-i.i.d. data)}}
  • {{c4::Actions affect subsequent data that is received}}

The Markov Decision Process is a five-tuple \((S,A,T,R,\gamma)\):
  • {{c1::\(S\): finite set of states (e.g. letters typed so far)}}
  • {{c2::\(A\): finite set of actions (e.g. what letter do I type next)}}
  • {{c3::\(T\): transition matrix containing \(p(s',a,s)\) - given a state and action, what is the probability of the next state \(s'\)}}
  • {{c4::\(R(s',a,s)\): reward of taking the action \(a\) in the state \(s\)}}
  • {{c5::\(y \in[0,1)\): discount factor}}
Markov Decision Process: A policy is {{c1::a mapping from state to action to maximize an expected cumulative reward}}.
A cognitive walkthrough is a {{c1::design walkthrough with a focus on ease-of-learning}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 1: {{c1::Visibility of System Status - keep users informed about what is going on.}}
Nielsen Heuristics - 2: {{c1::Match between system and the real world - Use familiar words and concepts, follow real-world conventions.}}
Nielsen Heuristics - 3: {{c1::User control and freedom - provide option to leave undesirable state (e.g. undo, cancel, return to home)}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 4: {{c1::Consistency and Standards - follow platform conventions, be consistent with words and concepts}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 5: {{c1::Error Prevention - Eliminate error-prone conditions, warn users with e.g. confirmation dialogs}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 6: {{c1::Recognition rather than recall - Make objects, actions, options visible. User should not have to remember information across dialogues}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 7: {{c1::Flexibility and efficiency of use - Offer accelerators (e.g. shortcuts) for experts, allow customizing frequent actions}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 8: {{c1::Aesthetic and minimalist design - do not show irrelevant or rarely needed information}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 9: {{c1::Help users recognize, diagnose and recover from errors - error messages should be in plain language, indicate the problem and suggest a solution}}.
Nielsen Heuristics - 10: {{c1::Help and documentation - best is no documentation, but if necessary it should be easy to search, focused on the task and list concrete steps to do}}.
In the GOMS model we focus on {{c2::the steps / processes involved when users do a task}}, whereas in KLM we want to {{c1::provide actual time predictions of how long doing the task will take}}.
